description: This adds functionality to export point clouds as PLY files which can then be uploaded to Sketchfab.
title: adding ply exporter

content.raw: I think you can move this function to module level, since you don't use `self`
content.html: I think you can move this function to module level, since you don't use self

content.raw: Imports should go at module level at the top of the file, not inline in the function, unless you can't avoid it for some reason (e.g. an import cycle). There are some imports in the other function you added as well that should be moved to module level.
content.html: Imports should go at module level at the top of the file, not inline in the function, unless you can't avoid it for some reason (e.g. an import cycle). There are some imports in the other function you added as well that should be moved to module level.

content.raw: the continuation characters are unnecessary here and above because you're inside parentheses
content.html: the continuation characters are unnecessary here and above because you're inside parentheses

content.raw: Left some minor style comments. It would be nice if this had a test too, in general we like to have tests for new functionality to avoid accidental breakage of the feature in the future.
content.html: Left some minor style comments. It would be nice if this had a test too, in general we like to have tests for new functionality to avoid accidental breakage of the feature in the future.

content.raw: Any specific format for tests?  Should I just put something in the "tests" subfolder?
content.html: Any specific format for tests? Should I just put something in the "tests" subfolder?

content.raw:
There's more info on writing and running unit tests in our developer guide: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/developing/testing.html#how-to-write-unit-tests

It could be something as simple as creating a `ply` file using fake data and then verifying that it's written to disk without crashing. If you know how, you could also verify that the resulting file is valid.

If you're looking for examples, grep the codebase for uses of `mkdtemp`, there are a number of tests that save files to disk in a temporary directory.
content.html:
There's more info on writing and running unit tests in our developer guide: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/developing/testing.html#how-to-write-unit-tests

It could be something as simple as creating a ply file using fake data and then verifying that it's written to disk without crashing. If you know how, you could also verify that the resulting file is valid.

If you're looking for examples, grep the codebase for uses of mkdtemp, there are a number of tests that save files to disk in a temporary directory.

content.raw: As far as the PLY string - from what I can tell you have to have all that specific stuff in the header.  Its possible we could add stuff to it, but I don't think we could take things away.
content.html: As far as the PLY string - from what I can tell you have to have all that specific stuff in the header. Its possible we could add stuff to it, but I don't think we could take things away.

content.raw: `unittest` needs to be removed too since you don't use it below.
content.html: unittest needs to be removed too since you don't use it below.

content.raw:
I think you need to retain the current directory and then explicitly switch back at the end of the test:

```
curdir = os.getcwd()
os.chdir(tmpdir)
... do test ...
os.chdir(curdir)
shutil.rmtree(tmpdir)
```
content.html:
I think you need to retain the current directory and then explicitly switch back at the end of the test:

curdir = os.getcwd()
os.chdir(tmpdir)
... do test ...
os.chdir(curdir)
shutil.rmtree(tmpdir)

content.raw: can be merged with `if` statement in the next line
content.html: can be merged with if statement in the next line

content.raw: it looks like that inner `if` could be moved outside. Perhaps right after `cs` definition in line 721? Why it's needed for py3?
content.html: it looks like that inner if could be moved outside. Perhaps right after cs definition in line 721? Why it's needed for py3?

I think that the remaining code could be reduced to:

if color_field is not None:
    mi = color_field_min or cs.min()
    ma = color_field_max or cs.max()
    if color_log:
        mi, ma, cs = np.log10((mi, ma, cs))

    cs = (cs - mi) / (ma - mi)
else:
    cs[:] = 1.0

content.raw: Why do we use `min(x)` and `max(x)` to scale `y` and `z`?
content.html: Why do we use min(x) and max(x) to scale y and z?

content.raw: Some of the code paths won't be tested this way. Could you export multiple *ply* files here? E.g. one with `decimator` set, one with `color_log` equal True, etc?
content.html: Some of the code paths won't be tested this way. Could you export multiple ply files here? E.g. one with decimator set, one with color_log equal True, etc?
